insights.insight: Ad tech charges $5–$150 CPA for modeled attribution; cryptographically verified receipts settle at roughly $0.10 each — a 50–200x cost delta that isn't a negotiating position, it's a structural difference in what's being sold.

With Chrome deprecating cookies and device fingerprinting increasingly blocked, the ad industry's two primary cross-site targeting primitives are functionally dead — verified purchase receipts are one of the few remaining deterministic signals that don't depend on either.

Best Buy's appearance in the top brand list marks the first major brick-and-mortar retailer in the dataset, signaling the protocol now reaches offline spend — higher average tickets, broader category diversity — that digital-only attribution methods cannot touch.

Unlike Fetch, Ibotta, or credit card data partnerships, DKIM-verified receipts confirm a purchase happened without attaching an identity — removing the primary legal and data-sharing friction that limits how ad tech can use purchase signals under GDPR and CCPA.

A Best Buy receipt processed through Gmail's DKIM infrastructure is simultaneously invisible to Apple, Google, Amazon, and Microsoft — the receipt layer captures cross-ecosystem purchase behavior that no single platform's first-party data can see.

Active metros expanded from 17 to 24 CBSAs in a single snapshot window — a 29% geographic spread that now includes non-metro and rural designations, indicating the signal base is broadening faster than prior growth patterns suggested.
